DataElement.preferredName: Gastric Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic Distant Metastasis M Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for the gastric cancer based on evidence obtained from pathologic examination through completion of definitive surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Relating to the stomach._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Relating to the stomach.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 12/3/18 tmt transferred context from NCIP. Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Gastric Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 7 Pathologic M Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A pathologic finding about one or more characteristics of gastric cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system as they pertain to distant metastases.  There is no pathologic M0 for gastric cancer. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Gastric cancer with distant metastasis. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

Concepts.longName: Gastric Cancer pM1 TNM Finding v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Gastric cancer with distant metastasis. (from AJCC 6th and 7th Eds.)

The extent of a cancer in the body.
